Hello Takashi,

I am not sure that rejecting unwilling URIs in the scheduler is a way to 
go. Maybe there is a case when this is needed, however I cannot see it. 
Do you have a case that you can share on this list? That might help me 
understand what exactly you are trying to do.

Also, send over the scheduler's decide rules and some URIs examples and 
I will take a look at it.

Take care,
i.


> Thanks Igor.
> 
> I feel very happy to have your kind reply and it cleared 
> up my question about the role of LinkScoper.
> DecideRuleSequence in decide-rules worked well and 
> I achieved crawls as I expected.
> 
> Now I have one more question. How about place some rules
> in Scheduler#decide-rules ? I placed rules rejecting
> some unwilling URIs in Scheduler#decide-rules as a test.
> But when vieweing Frontier URIs by pausing the job,
> those unwilling URIs showed up in the Frontier URIs.
> 
> Anyway, as I wrote at the begging of this post,
> my crawlings are comming along using DecideRuleSequence 
> in decide-rules. I say thanks again, Igor.
> 
> 
> --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Igor Ranitovic <igor@...> wrote:
>> Hello Takashi,
>>
>> I suggest that you use the DecidingScope to scope the crawler.
>> To learn more about this scope check the user manual here:
>>
> http://crawler.archive.org/articles/user_manual/config.html#decidingscope
>> By studying the decide rules you will learn that most common way to 
>> reject URIs is via regular expressions and SURT prefixes within the 
>> DecidingScope sequence.
>>
>> LinkScoper rules on which extracted (not scheduled) links, of a crawled 
>> URI, are within the scope. Links that are not in the scope are 
>> disregarded. The links that are in the scope are "promoted" to 
>> CandidateURIs (if not CandidateURIs already) and later scheduled to be 
>> crawled.
>>
>> The decide rules of the LinkScoper itself simply decide if the
>> LinkScoper will be skipped the next processor in the processor chain
> or not.
>> If the LinkScoper is skipped, I believe that getting ClassCastException 
>> errors is to be expected.  The extractors create Link and not 
>> CandidateURI links needed by Scheduler. However, if you use your own 
>> extractors that create CAndidateURI links, skipping the LinkScoper 
>> simple means that all extracted links will be scheduled.
>>
>> If you want to reject already schedule links, that can be done with 
>> Preselector's options like recheck-scope, block-all and etc.
>>
>> I hope this helps.
>>
>>
>> Take care,
>> i.
